qas.question: Italian is significantly mutually comprehensible with what other Romance language?
With what romance language does Spanish not have a high degree of mutual comprehensibility?
What is the reason for French and Italian not being very mutually comprehensible?

answers.text: French having undergone more rapid and more pervasive phonological change

qas.question: This pattern is particularly lacking among which modern languages?
Which languages have a low degree of  mutual comprehensibility?
What do both the Italian and Spanish languages share with the French language?

plausible_answers.text: French having undergone more rapid and more pervasive phonological change than have Spanish and Italian

qas.question: What is French-Spanish and Spanish-Italian mutual incomprehensibility due to?
Which two languages share numerous root words that aren't even in the Romance language?

context: This can give rise to the situation in which two dialects (defined according to this paradigm) with a somewhat distant genetic relationship are mutually more readily comprehensible than more closely related dialects. In one opinion, this pattern is clearly present among the modern <b3_0>Romance<b3_0/> languages, with <b4_0>Italian and <a0_0>Spanish<b4_0/><a0_0/> having a <b5_0>high degree of mutual comprehensibility<b5_0/>, which neither language shares with <a1_0>French<a1_0/>, despite some claiming that both languages are genetically closer to French than to each other:[citation needed] In fact, French-Italian and French-Spanish relative mutual incomprehensibility is due to <a2_0><b6_0>French having undergone more rapid and more pervasive phonological change<a2_0/> than have Spanish and Italian<b6_0/>, not to real or imagined distance in genetic relationship. In fact, <b7_0>Italian and French<b7_0/> share many more root words in common that do not even appear in Spanish.
